Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

An object of height <math alttext="uppercase H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the principal axis is located to the left of a concave lens, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The distance from the lens to its focal point is <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, and the distance from the lens to the object is <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase D is greater than f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mo>></mo><mi>f</mi></math>. Also shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is a ray originating from the top of the object and directed toward the center of the lens.

(a)

i. On Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, draw the following.

One additional ray, originating from the top of the object, that can be used to find the location of the image formed by the lens

An arrow that represents the location, height, and orientation of the image

The concave lens is removed and replaced with another lens, Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, which is convex and has the same distance <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> to its focal point as the original lens. The object is still located a distance <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> to the left of the lens.

ii. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the height of the image formed by the lens. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="uppercase H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
Note: If you need to draw anything other than what you have shown in part (a)(i) to assist in your solution, use the space below. Do NOT add anything to Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

(b)
Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is now replaced with Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is convex and the same size and shape as Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, but it is made of a material with an index of refraction that is greater than the refractive index of the material in Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Indicate where the image formed by Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> will be located compared to the image formed by Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Assume that the image is formed on the same side of the lens for both Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.
_____ The image is at the same location for both lenses.
_____ The image is closer to the lens for Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> than it was for Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
_____ The image is farther from the lens for Lens <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> than it was for Lens <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
Justify your answer using physics principles.
